Award.AwardTitle: Changing Agrarian Foundations Of Urban Life: A Long-Term Perspective

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The central goal of this research is to understand how within traditional societies (such as those which characterize many parts of the developing world today) urban and rural dwellers are linked together through social and economic ties and how these linkages are affected by environmental change. Archaeology provides an excellent context for analyses of this type because it can trace and correlate changes in social organization and environmental context sometimes over millennial time scales.

This NSF-supported investigation will reconstruct the economic foundations of agrarian life through time in the northern Maya area in Yucatan, Mexico. The power and complexity of the economic foundations of pre-modern states is acutely reflected in the impacts that governmental institutions had on the humblest, most peripheral residents of society. Such effects can be positive, neutral, or negative. For example, thriving market networks can connect rural houselots to larger spheres of interaction with the outside world that bring opportunities for affluence and occupational specialization. Alternatively, commoners situated within a matrix of competitive city states may suffer suppressed opportunities for prosperity, due to higher levels of taxation or instability associated with warfare. Of equal importance are bottom-up processes by which ordinary citizens innovate or reproduce economic strategies that foster household maintenance and survival. Understanding the economic organization of rural populations is essential for evaluating the prospects for a sustainable agrarian food base needed to support urban towns and cities of this arid region.

The primary research objective is to document the degree of diversity in farming, craft production, and service industries that characterized the work lives of rural residential groups through time. Related factors will also be evaluated, including the degree of wealth, stability, and longevity of the hinterland commoner house groups, as well as their level of dependency on local and regional exchange for the essentials of daily life. An extensive program of household archaeology will provide the data needed to address these research objectives, building on a previous NSF-supported investigation that located thousands of dwellings across a continuously-occupied area of 40 square kilometers, using LiDAR remote sensing. Rural life in two contrastive political geographic settings will be compared. Initially, Late and Terminal Classic era houselots were located in an extremely marginal position, far from towns or cities of significant size. Later, Postclassic homesteads were within four kilometers of a major political capital, the site of Mayap√°n, a large urban center that emerged in this area. This study will document the resulting transformations to regional political economy. The study will examine long term viable strategies for farming in a drought-prone environment in an area that suffered repeated catastrophic demographic collapses, followed by remarkable resilience and demographic recovery. Although prior surface surveys revealed that the Yucatecan countryside was surprisingly populous in ancient times, with rural densities of at least 6 persons per hectare across vast tracts of the outback, no prior study has targeted the household economies of the non-urban Maya countryside.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Agrarian Foundations of Mayapan project investigated the degree of wealth, labor diversification, economic autonomy, and occupational longevity at Maya rural houses in the northern Plains of Yucatan in the Pre-Columbian era. This study focused on transitions in household economy over a 400 year period, from A.D. 950-1450, an interval that encompasses the collapse of Terminal Classic Period Maya states (950-1050) and a subsequent political coalescence by 1250 with the establishment of the Postclassic Mayapan state. Little is known of the diversity, self-sufficiency, or regional economic interdependence of families in agrarian zones that extended almost continuously through the countryside that linked together settlements of better-documented cities and towns. Data from urban centers reflects a complex regional commercial economy, with significant inter-household dependencies promoted occupational specialization (craft production, etc.) and market trade across the Yucatan peninsula. But the lifeways of urban commoners are not fully representative of the lower class in ancient Maya society; documenting hinterland economies provides a more robust view.

Survey archaeologists have for many years mapped the surface remains of abundant, sometimes continuous tracts of humble houses between major and minor centers of the Classic and Postclassic Periods in northern Yucatan. These findings imply high population levels and good agricultural productivity in this region, the driest of the Maya world with notoriously shallow soils. Rural agriculturalists would have generated surplus crops essential to sustain cities and towns of thousands of inhabitants. But surface survey work provides no data regarding the social and economic patterns of daily life needed to fully reconstruct regional demography and the foundations of political economies. One prior (now-refuted) view held that rural houses were only seasonal farmsteads temporarily occupied by townspeople. Our 2015 project is one of the first to fully investigate and compare farmers’ household economies through time in northern Yucatan.

Our team excavated eight houses in eight weeks, four each from the Terminal Classic and Postclassic periods. The selection of houses was aided by our 2013 NSF-funded LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) survey research that yielded a surface map of 40 square kilometers of all manmade (Pre-Columbian) structures beneath the forest canopy. Excavations targeted small, humble dwellings from the LiDAR survey that fit the project’s goal of investigating rural zone commoners exhibiting diverse spatial locations, architectural characteristics, and time periods. We presented preliminary findings at the Society of American Archaeology conference (Orlando, April 2016). Data and reports in preparation for the Mexican government will be shared with the public via the TDAR website and publications are planned.

The eight excavated residences were occupied during two highly contrastive regional settings, both rural, but different in terms of their proximity to urban centers. For the Terminal Classic, our sample tested dwellings that were exceptionally remote (30 km) from the nearest third tier town in the regional hierarchy. For the Postclassic Period, rural houses lay within one to two km from the largest urban capital of the Maya world of this time period, Mayapan, a city with 12-15,000 persons living inside its circumferential wall.

The question of occupational longevity was resolved by documentation significant investment in residential house platform construction at seven of the eight houses for which tons of rock fill were required. The presence of specialized storeroom buildings, multiple construction episodes, and burials also attested to the duration of occupation, in contrast to the “seasonal farmstead” model. These results are significant for reconstructing higher countryside population levels.

Two houses within 250-500 meters of a minor temple groups in the hinterland exhibited greater wealth and activity diversification, despite the modest characteristics of these dwellings. This pattern was a matter of degree, with greater density, diversity, and valuable materials at two of the eight houses, but most importantly, the majority of houses obtained nonlocal goods (raw materials and finished products of shell, chert, or pottery) through trade. Obsidian, a long distance good, was acquired by seven of eight households. Low levels of production debris (using nonlocal chert and shell) indicates that household activities were slightly diversified in these rural dwellings and that the primary activity was farming. These agriculturalists did not make large quantities of craft goods like the commoners of urban Mayapan. But most importantly, there are no indications of household “autonomy” or dire poverty for either period as traditionally thought for pre-modern agrarian peasants. Although they were poorer than their urban counterparts, these rural households relied to an important degree on regional and long distance commercial networks. Also significant is the variation of wealth and residential growth among rural houselots of each period, and our data reflect the contingencies of social group histories in the countryside. Modest affluence suggests that these occupants profited from the exchange of some of the foodstuffs that they produced.
